localizedDescriptions.en: Interaction, contact or care event between a subject of care and healthcare provider(s).
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Covid_19_Admission
The patient was admitted to hospital.
The patient was not admitted to hospital.
It is not known if the patient was admitted to hospital.
Details about the age of an individual.
Age based on actual date of birth.
Age based on due date.
Additional narrative about the age of an individual, not captured in other fields.

annotations.comment: For example: pre-term delivery

localizedDescriptions.en: An individual- or self-reported questionnaire screening for symptoms and signs.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The reason for overall screening.

annotations.comment: For example: screening for an infectious disease, such as SARS-COV-2.

children.name: Presence of any symptoms or signs?
children.localizedName: Presence of any symptoms or signs?

localizedNames.en: Presence of any symptoms or signs?

localizedDescriptions.en: Presence of any relevant symptoms or signs.
Symptoms or signs are present.
Symptoms or signs are not present.
It is not known whether any symptoms or signs are present or absent.

children.name: Onset of any symptoms or signs
children.localizedName: Onset of any symptoms or signs

localizedNames.en: Onset of any symptoms or signs

localizedDescriptions.en: The date/time when any symptoms or signs were first noticed.

annotations.comment: Partial dates are allowed.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about all symptoms or signs.
Grouping of data elements related to screening for a single symptom or sign.
Name of the symptom or sign being screened.
Presence of the symptom or sign.
The specific symptom or sign is present.
The specific symptom or sign is not present.
It is not known whether the symptom or sign is present or absent.
Additional narrative about the specific symptom or sign, not captured in other fields.
Additional narrative about the symptoms and signs, not captured in other fields.
An individual- or self-reported questionnaire screening for conditions, including problems, diagnoses and pregnancy.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The reason for overall screening.

annotations.comment: For example: pre-operative screening.

localizedDescriptions.en: Presence of any relevant conditions.
Conditions are present.
Conditions are not present.
It is not known whether any conditions are present or absent.
Grouping of data elements related to screening for a single condition.
Name of the condition being screened.
Presence of the condition.
The specific condition is present.
The specific condition is not present.
It is not known whether the condition is present or absent.
The date/time when the condition was first noticed by the individual or diagnosed by a clinician.

annotations.comment: Partial dates are allowed.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the specific condition, not captured in other fields.
The date/time when any conditions were first noticed.
The date/time when any conditions were first noticed.
The date/time when any conditions were first noticed.
Between first day of last period and the end of week 12.
Between week 13 and week 28.
After week 28.

annotations.comment: Partial dates are allowed.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the conditions, not captured in other fields.
An individual- or self-reported questionnaire screening for management or treatment carried out.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The reason for overall screening.

annotations.comment: For example: screening for an infectious disease, such as SARS-COV-2.

localizedDescriptions.en: Grouping of data elements related to screening for a single management or treatment activity.
Name of the management or treatment activity being screened.
Did the management or treatment activity take place?
The specific management activity was carried out.
The specific management activity was not carried out.
It is not known whether the management activity was carried out.
The date/time when the management or treatment activity was carried out.

annotations.comment: Partial dates are allowed.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the specific management or treatment activity, not captured in other fields.
Additional narrative about all management and treatment activities, not captured in other fields.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
A measurement of the body temperature, which is a surrogate for the core body temperature of the individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The measured temperature.
Additional comment about the body temperature measurement not captured in other fields.
The degree of exposure of the individual at the time of measurement.
No clothing, bedding or covering.
The person is covered by a lesser amount of clothing or bedding than deemed appropriate for the environmental circumstances.
The person is covered by an amount of clothing or bedding deemed appropriate for the environmental circumstances.
The person is covered by an increased amount of clothing or bedding than deemed appropriate for the environmental circumstances.
Narrative description of the conditions applied to the subject that might influence their measured body temperature.
Current day of the menstrual cycle.

annotations.comment: The first day of menstruation is considered to be Day 1 of each menstrual cycle.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional issues or factors that may impact on the measurement of body temperature, not captured in other fields.
Simple description about the site of measurement.
Temperature measured within the rectum.
Temperature is measured from the skin of the axilla with the arm positioned down by the side.
Temperature is measured from within the external auditory canal.
Temperature is measured on the forehead.
Temperature is measured within the mouth.
Temperature is measured within the nasopharynx.
Temperature is measured in the urinary bladder.
Temperature is measured within the vascular system.
Temperature is measured from exposed skin.
Temperature is measured within the vagina.
Temperatue is measured within the oesophagus.
Temperature is measured in the inguinal skin crease between the leg and abdominal wall.
Temperature is measured at the temple, over the superficial temporal artery.
The characteristics of spontaneous breathing by an individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Observation of spontaneous respiration.
Respiratory movements are observed.
Respiratory movements are not detected on observation.

annotations.comment: This data element may be useful in extreme situations where a formal measurement of respiration rate is not possible. For example: a subject is unconscious and distant to the observer, such as trapped in a car or has fallen down a cliff. Presence of respiration can be implied if the 'Rate' >0 breaths/min.

localizedDescriptions.en: The frequency of spontaneous breathing.
The regularity of spontaneous breathing.
The breathing pattern is regular.
The breathing pattern is not regular.
The depth of spontaneous breathing.
Normal depth of breathing.
Shallow depth of breathing.
Deep breathing.
Variable depth of breathing.
A narrative description about the spontaneous breathing of the individual.

annotations.comment:
For example: noting respiratory distress, use of accessory muscles or intermittent apnoea; noting characteristics such as stridor, sighing, grunting, groaning, gasping. 
Conducting a full respiratory examination, then some of these findings might be more appropriately recorded as part of examination findings.

localizedDescriptions.en: Single word, phrase or brief description which represents the clinical meaning and significance of the respiration findings.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: Normal breathing; Evidence of respiratory distress; Kussmaul's respiration; Cheyne-Stokes respiration; or Apnoeic episodes. Multiple statements are allowed.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the respirations, not captured in other fields.
The body position of the individual during the observation.
The individual was standing, walking or running.
The individual was sitting (for example, on a bed or chair).
The individual was reclining at an approximate angle of 45 degrees, with the legs elevated to the level of the pelvis.
The individual was lying on their back.
The individual was lying on their front.
Identification of any issues or incidental factors that may impact on interpretation of the observation.

annotations.comment: For example: level of anxiety, pain, feeding in infants, tracheostomy.

localizedDescriptions.en: Blood oxygen and related measurements, measured by pulse oximetry or pulse CO-oximetry.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The saturation of oxygen in the peripheral blood, measured via pulse oximetry.

annotations.comment: SpO is defined as the percentage of oxyhaemoglobin (HbO) to the total concentration of haemoglobin (HbO + deoxyhaemoglobin) in peripheral blood.

localizedDescriptions.en: Single word, phrase or brief description which represents the clinical meaning and significance of the measurements.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is preferred, if possible. For example, normal oxygen saturation or hypoxaemia.

localizedDescriptions.en: Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be affect interpretation of the observation.

annotations.comment: For example, motion, pain, poor perfusion, infant feeding, peripheral hypothermia, sedation.

localizedDescriptions.en: An individual- or self-reported questionnaire screening for travel activity.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Has the individual travelled during the specified interval?
The individual has travelled within the specified interval of time.
The individual has not travelled within the specified interval of time.
It is unknown whether the individual has travelled within the specified interval of time.

annotations.comment: Use the Event to set the relevant interval.

localizedDescriptions.en: Was the travel domestic, international, or both?
The individual has travelled domestically within the specified interval of time.
The individual has travelled internationally within the specified interval of time.
The individual has travelled both domestically and internationally within the specified interval of time.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
The result, including findings and the laboratory's interpretation, of an investigation performed on specimens collected from an individual or related to that individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Name of the laboratory investigation performed on the specimen(s).

annotations.comment: A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests. It is strongly recommended that 'Test name' be coded with a terminology, for example LOINC or SNOMED CT. For example: 'Glucose', 'Urea and Electrolytes', 'Swab', 'Cortisol (am)', 'Potassium in perspiration' or 'Melanoma histopathology'. The name may sometimes include specimen type and patient state, for example 'Fasting blood glucose' or include other information, as 'Potassium (PNA blood gas)'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The status of the laboratory test result as a whole.
The existence of the test is registered in the Laboratory Information System, but there is nothing yet available.
This is a partial (e.g. initial, interim or preliminary) Test Result: data in the Test Result may be incomplete or unverified.
Verified early results are available, but not all results are final. This is a sub-category of 'Partial'.
The Test result is complete and verified by an authorised person.
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist, and result data has been changed.
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist. This is a sub-category of 'Amended'.
Subsequent to being final, the report has been modified by adding new content. The existing content is unchanged. This is a sub-category of 'Amended'.
The result is unavailable because the test was not started or not completed (also sometimes called 'aborted').
The Test Result has been withdrawn following previous Final release.

annotations.comment:
The values have been specifically chosen to match those in the HL7 FHIR Diagnostic report, historically derived from HL7v2 practice. Other local codes/terms can be used via the Text 'choice'.

This element is multiple occurrence to cater for the use cases where statuses for different aspects of the result have been split into several elements.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date and/or time that Overall test status was issued.
The diagnostic service or discipline that is responsible for the laboratory test result.

annotations.comment: This is intended to be a general categorisation and not to capture the organisational name of the laboratory. For example: anatomical pathology, immunology and transfusion medicine, medical microbiology, clinical pharmacology, medical genetics, medical biochemistry. Alternatively more granular sub categories or sub disciplines, such as endocrinology, haematology, and allergology services, may be used. This may assist clinicians in filtering between categories of results. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Description of clinical information available at the time of interpretation of results.

annotations.comment: This data element may include a link to the original clinical information provided in the test request.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the key findings.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Pattern suggests significant renal impairment'. The content of the conclusion will vary, depending on the investigation performed. This conclusion should be aligned with the coded 'Test diagnosis'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the laboratory test result.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Severe hepatic impairment', 'Salmonella contamination'. Coding of the diagnosis with a terminology is strongly recommended, where possible. This diagnosis should be aligned with the narrative in the 'Conclusion'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the test result not captured in other fields.
Issues or circumstances that impact on the accurate interpretation of the measurement or test result.

annotations.comment:
'Confounding factors' should be reserved for uncontrolled/unplanned issues of patient state/physiology that might affect interpretation, for example 'recent exercise' or 'recent tobacco smoking'.

Known or required preconditions, such as 'fasting' should be carried in the 'Sampling conditions' element within the CLUSTER.specimen archetype . In some cases preconditions are captured as part of the test name, for example 'Fasting blood glucose'.

Known issues with specimen collection or handling, such as 'prolonged use of tourniquet' or 'sample haemolysed', should be carried in the 'Specimen quality' elements within CLUSTER.specimen archetype.

Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: A local identifier assigned by the receiving Laboratory Information System (LIS) to track the test process.
A local identifier assigned by the receiving Laboratory Information System (LIS) to track the test process.
A local identifier assigned by the receiving Laboratory Information System (LIS) to track the test process.

annotations.comment: This identifier is an internal tracking number assigned by the LIS, and it not intended to be the name of the test.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about the test request.
Name of the original laboratory test requested.

annotations.comment: This data element is to be used when the test requested differs from the test actually performed by the laboratory.

localizedDescriptions.en: The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.
The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.
The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.

annotations.comment: Equivalent to the HL7 Placer Order Identifier.

localizedDescriptions.en: The local identifier assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the Laboratory Information System (LIS).
The local identifier assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the Laboratory Information System (LIS).
The local identifier assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the Laboratory Information System (LIS).

annotations.comment: Assigning an identifier to a request by the Laboratory lnformation System (LIS) enables tracking progress of the request and enables linking results to requests. It also provides a reference to assist with enquiries and it is usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier.

In most situations there is one test request and a single corresponding test result, however this repeating cluster allows for the situation where there may be multiple test requests reported using a single test result.

As an example: 'a clinician asks for blood glucose in one request and Urea/electrolytes in a second request, but the lab analyser does both and the lab wishes to report these together'.

localizedDescriptions.en: This indicates whether the test was performed directly at Point-of-Care (POCT) as opposed to a formal result from a laboratory or other service delivery organisation.

annotations.comment: True if the test was performed directly at Point-of-Care (POCT).

localizedDescriptions.en: A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Assessment of the potential and likelihood of Covid-19 infection as determined by identified risk factors.
Identification of the potential future disease, condition or health issue for which the risk is being assessed, by name.
Assessment of risk of COVID-19 infection.

annotations.comment: Coding of 'Health risk' with a terminology is preferred, where possible. Free text should be used only if there is no appropriate terminology available. For example: risk of cardiovascular disease, with risk factors of hypertension and hypercholesterolaemia.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about each possible risk factor.
Identification of the risk factor, by name.
Contact with confirmed Covid-19 case within 14 days before symptom onset.

list.label: Potential contact exposure based on location

localizedLabels.en: Potential contact exposure based on location

localizedDescriptions.en: Potential contact exposure based on location.

list.label: Contact with suspected case/ pneumonia case

localizedLabels.en: Contact with suspected case/ pneumonia case

localizedDescriptions.en: Contact with suspected case/ pneumonia case within 14 days before symptom onset.

list.label: Contact with severe, unexplained respiratory disease

localizedLabels.en: Contact with severe, unexplained respiratory disease

localizedDescriptions.en: Contact with severe, unexplained respiratory disease in 10 days before symptom onset.
Contact with birds in China in 10 days before symptom onset.

list.label: Contact with confirmed human case of Avian flu in China

localizedLabels.en: Contact with confirmed human case of Avian flu in China

localizedDescriptions.en: Contact with confirmed human case of Avian flu in China in 10 days before symptom onset.
Does the patient require hospital admission with either clinical or radiological evidence of pneumonia, adult respiratory distress syndrome, or influenza like illness?
The patient is in a house with other household members who are ill
Members of the patient's household have travel exposure.

annotations.comment:
For example: hypertension and hypercholesterolaemia, which may be used as part of the overall assessment for cardiovascular disease; or a genetic marker. Coding of 
'Risk factor' with a terminology, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Presence of the risk factor.
The risk factor has been identified for this individual.
The risk factor has not been identified for this individual.
No information is available for this risk factor.
Narrative description about the risk factor.
The date/time that the risk factor was identified.
The risk factor has been identified as present, but then subsequently been mitigated by treatment or investigation.

annotations.comment: Record as True if the risk factor has been treated or investigated and risk from this risk factor is considered to be lessened. For example: an infant given gentamicin in neonatal intensive care is regarded as having a risk of permanent hearing loss. If diagnostic testing shows no evidence of hearing loss in the first year of life, the risk of later hearing loss is considered to be much reduced, but still possible. This data element allows clinicians to say that the risk has been mitigated but should still be considered as a possibility in future. In practice, the risk factor could be maintained in the risk assessment in case it might impact the individual's health at a future time, but flagging that its contribution to risk calculation may not be as great as if it had not been previously treated or investigated.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the path to the archetype or data node for the evidence of risk.
Additional narrative about the risk factor not captured in other fields.
Evaluation of the health risk.
The risk of the a patient having a Covid-19 infection is assessed to be low.
The risk of the a patient having a Covid-19 infection is assessed to be high.

annotations.comment: There may be multiple variations on the assessment of risk. The Choice data type allows for recording of the assessment as either free text or value sets (such as low, medium or hig). The proportion data type allows recording of a percentage, a ratio or a fraction. The quantity data type allows recording of a decimal number.

localizedDescriptions.en: Record of whether the risk assessment is a relative or absolute.
Ratio of probability of a health event or condition occurring compared to a population with similar characteristics eg same age and sex.
Ratio of probability of a health event or condition occurring compared to the population as a whole.
The time period during which the predicted health risk is relevant.

annotations.comment: That is: the risk of experiencing the identified 'Health risk' in the next <X> years.

localizedDescriptions.en: Justification for this risk assessment.

annotations.comment: Details that may be added to this data element may include information about the population subgroups etc against which the determination of risk is assessed.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the risk assessment not captured in other fields.
The date this health risk assessment was last updated.

annotations.comment: This data element may be thought redundant if the data is recorded and stored using COMPOSITIONs within a closed clinical system. However if this information is extracted from its original COMPOSITION context, for example, to be included in another document or message then the temporal context is effectively removed. This 'Last updated' data element has been explicitly added to allow the critical temporal data to be kept alongside the clinical data in all circumstances. It is assumed that the clinical system can copy the date from the COMPOSITION to reduce the need for duplication of data entry by the clinician.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the algorithm or guideline used to make the assessment of risk.

annotations.comment: For example: Framingham cardiovascular risk calculator.

localizedDescriptions.en: A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Details about a single identified health condition, injury, disability or any other issue which impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual.
Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name.

annotations.comment: Coding of the name of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about the problem or diagnosis.

annotations.comment: Use to provide background and context, including evolution, episodes or exacerbations, progress and any other relevant details, about the problem or diagnosis.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of a simple body site for the location of the problem or diagnosis.

annotations.comment:
Coding of the name of the anatomical location with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Use this data element to record precoordinated anatomical locations. If the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations then use the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location within the 'Structured anatomical location' SLOT in this archetype. Occurrences for this data element are unbounded to allow for clinical scenarios such as describing a rash in multiple locations but where all of the other attributes are identical. If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: Estimated or actual date/time that signs or symptoms of the problem/diagnosis were first observed.

annotations.comment: Data captured/imported as "Age at onset" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.

localizedDescriptions.en: Estimated or actual date/time the diagnosis or problem was recognised by a healthcare professional.

annotations.comment: Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of clinical recognition" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.

localizedDescriptions.en: An assessment of the overall severity of the problem or diagnosis.
The problem or diagnosis does not interfere with normal activity or may cause damage to health if left untreated.
The problem or diagnosis causes interference with normal activity or will damage health if left untreated.
The problem or diagnosis prevents normal activity or will seriously damage health if left untreated.

annotations.comment: If severity is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant. Note: more specific grading of severity can be recorded using the Specific details SLOT.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about the course of the problem or diagnosis since onset.
Estimated or actual date/time of resolution or remission for this problem or diagnosis, as determined by a healthcare professional.

annotations.comment: Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of resolution" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.

localizedDescriptions.en: The level of confidence in the identification of the diagnosis.
The diagnosis has been identified with a low level of certainty.
The diagnosis has been identified with a high level of certainty.
The diagnosis has been confirmed against recognised criteria.
Additional narrative about the problem or diagnosis not captured in other fields.
The date this problem or diagnosis was last updated.

annotations.comment: Clear delineation between the scope of a problem versus a diagnosis is not easy to achieve in practice. For the purposes of clinical documentation with this archetype, problem and diagnosis are regarded as a continuum, with increasing levels of detail and supportive evidence usually providing weight towards the label of 'diagnosis'.
